Hi Martin, yes I think actually from my understanding of biology that bil=
ateral symmetry in the human line, which starts with the flatworm long ago,=
 was indeed evolved from an earlier radial symmetry.  But my point is more =
about how a regularity (or irregularity) was *preserved* as opposed to how =
it was *achieved*.  No matter how a particular organizational principle com=
es about (now I'm being more careful to avoid suggesting it's more or less =
regular than before), the problem is that there is no reason for evolution =
to reward and thereby preserve it in an objective setting when it's first d=
iscovered.  So whether or not bilateral symmetry comes from a reduction in =
regularity or an increase in regularity, if the first bilaterally symmetric=
 individual does not look very close to the final objective (and it most li=
kely does not) then it is likely to be selected out and lost by an objectiv=
e-driven search.

You also make an interesting point in the sense that conc=
entrating too much on the word "symmetry" in discussing these matters misse=
s the fact that there is a risk of losing conventions of any type, whether =
or not they increase regularity.  In fact, the change from radial symmetry =
to bilateral symmetry is not simply a story of reduced organization because=
 the new asymmetric axis in bilaterally symmetric organisms itself is still=
 organized in the sense that it represents a gradient from head to tail.  T=
hat gradient is a fundamental organizing principle as much as the bilateral=
 symmetry.  The word "irregular" can cause us to forget how important such =
non-symmetric principles are in organizing body plans as well.

ken
